18. Function-3: synthesis and its declarative function. ◊
Some of the following terminology that will be explained more fully later in § 44:
• alētheia-1 = ex-sistence as the sphere of intelligibility, the so-called “clearing”;
• alētheia-2 = the intelligibility of something when taken as this or that, whether correctly or not;
• alētheia-3 = the truth of a correct statement.
Close
We said that the first function of logos is to make sense of something, whether correctly or not, by drawing the meaning from the way the thing itself shows up rather than from my feelings or wishes about the thing. Given this apophantic/ de-clarative function, a logos can have the structure of a synthesis—not, however, in the sense of synthesizing “things out there” with “ideas in here” (my “inner mental states”), where the problem then becomes how “interior” mental states can agree with “exterior” physical objects.
The Greek word synthesis is made up of two elements: -thesis, placing something, and syn, together with something else. In the case of logos as synthesis, the syn- has a purely apophantic/declarative function: someone claims, whether correctly or not, that S (a certain thing) is to be synthesized with and understood in terms of P (a meaning drawn from the thing as it appears).
